title: Thursday, 11th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

Cost of Revenue Leverage and Growing Engagement Is Encouraging Despite Mixed First-Quarter Results

PM11:05am

Moreover, we still believe Snap is at an early stage in its monetization ramp and can gain share in a rapidly growing video and social advertising market. During the quarter, the company also noted increased engagement with the app and pointed to positive signs that its API initiative is starting to gain traction. Over 20% of impressions served came from the API, which,in our view,is a positive metric given the product is just six months into release.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

BE11:07am

BE11:07am

So, sure, bad quarter!

11:07 am
BE11:07am

By the metric of DOA or whatever.

BE11:08am

But we're literally inventing metrics on which to fantasise a valuation case here, and it's totally irrelevant.

BE11:08am

Because it's not an investment in the conventional sense, or probably in any sense.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

It's just a trial of the strength of collective delusion.

PM11:09am

hmm

BE11:09am

Public markets are broken. So can we make this work? This nonsense business that has no economic value?

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Can we make public markets into a kind of socialist, distributed alternative to unicorn VC?

BE11:10am

Maybe! One bad quarter doesn't change much, as the sellside demonstrates.

BE11:11am

You have to believe in unicorns otherwise they stop existing. Snap's the public market fairytale to prove that dictum.

11:10 am
PM11:11am

Well, I'm maintaining our virtual Sell on this

PM11:11am

At $17.80, sell into any bounce

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Fantasy politics in full here, btw https://www.ft.com...-bce4-9023f8c0fd2e

BE11:17am

In addition to the ex div, we have JPM doing the numbers on the other side's manifesto

BE11:17am

and its Marxist price controls.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And it seems to have surprised JPM that the price cap could do exactly as advertised.

BE11:18am

As in, cut bills by about £100.

BE11:19am

Now, you'll remember a couple of days ago I went on a long waffle about how the SVT price cap will work and how it can be offset by hedging which has the effect of homogenising the market.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

In effect, creating a pricing cartel among the big six as they hedge off the cap benchmark.

BE11:20am

JPM disagrees! Mostly, it disagrees because it expects a price war.

BE11:20am

Here's the first bit.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Despite the strength of CNA’s UK supply operations, two issues that have recently arisen deeply concern us. Firstly, we see significant downside emerging through price regulation of CNA’s core ‘Standard Variable Tariff’ (SVT) customer base. Our initial view of the damage to EPS was negative, but manageable at -10% to -20% (see here). Yet our analysis of Ofgem’s regulated prepayment meter (PPM) tariffs – the main focus of this report – points to a deeper EPS erosion at up to -42%. Secondly, we see evidence of a price war emerging, with incumbent generation owner ENGIE entering the residential supply market with heavily discounted residential tariffs. Having lost customers in Q1 (at an annualised rate of 7.5%), CNA has already been forced to respond with heavily discounted offers via its Sainsbury’s brand. We are downgrading CNA from OW to UW with a Dec-17 PT of 180p (265p).

BE11:21am

So ........

BE11:21am

· SVT caps cut more deeply than first thought – While the reintroduction of price regulation after a 15-year period of liberalisation was a surprise to us, UK prepayment meter (PPM) regulation introduced earlier this year provides a body of regulatory data on which to accurately model its impact. We have undertaken a full review of Ofgem’s PPM tariff materials, which has alarming implications for CNA’s supply margins. For instance, if regulated price caps were in place in 2016 we estimate that dual fuel bills would have been a full £100/cust lower on average for the Big 6.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

..... but perhaps more interestingly ....

BE11:21am

· Price war on the horizon? – Warning bells will have started to ring for the Big 6 on the news that Engie has cut its UK dual fuel offering to less than £900 last month. CNA (-£160/cust), e.on (-£70/cust) and npower (-£73/cust) have responded with tariff reductions. All eyes are now on SSE, Scottish and EDF, who elected to lift fixed tariffs by £140, £90 and £50, respectively.

BE11:21am

therefore .........

11:21 am
BE11:22am

· Downgrading estimates – Based on our PPM tariff analysis, SVT price regulation could reduce CNA’s margins by up to ~£90/cust after normalising for wholesale fuel costs, significantly more than our prior projections. Our revised earnings forecasts include a £50/cust reduction in SVT margins (~£300m at EBIT) which is the main factor behind our EPS downgrades of 26% and 31% in FY18 and FY19, respectively.

BE11:22am

While in the sector, we should also note that Berenberg's turned cautious on National Grid.

National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 1,034, down 5.5 (-0.53%), High: 1,037, Low: 1,029, Volume: 1.48m
11:23 am
BE11:23am

● Investment case played out: When we upgraded National Grid to Buy in
January, the investment case was very simple: in our opinion, the share
price did not reflect the value of the forthcoming 84.375p special dividend
(ex-div 22 May). That has now played out and the shares are trading close
to our unchanged 1,050p price target. Consequently, we are downgrading
our rating to Hold.
● Temporary timing factors behind upgrade to near-term forecasts: There
can be a mismatch between allowed and recovered revenue. A catch-up is
sometimes required. National Grid has announced that timing factors in
the UK (UKET) and the US add roughly 7p (previously 2p) to 2016/17E EPS.
This represents the lion’s share of our estimate changes. The catch-up
effects are, of course, only temporary. Eventually, revenues will normalise.

BE11:24am

● Longer-term forecasts little changed: Nevertheless, we make some subtle
changes to the mix, with lower growth expectations for UK Electricity Transmission (less growth in the regulatory asset base (RAB)), offset by a higher expected contribution from non-regulated activities (interconnectors) and lower financial expenses. We also make a few tweaks to FX and tax.
● UK general election and risks: UK residential energy bills are once again under fire in the pre-election campaigns. This is more of an issue for supply companies like Centrica, SSE, E.ON, EDF, Iberdrola and innogy than National Grid. That said, National Grid’s growth prospects could be hampered if government intervention prolongs the investment hiatus in new capacity.

BE11:25am

● Special dividend: The group plans to return the vast majority of proceeds from its recent Gas Distribution disposal to shareholders via an 84.375p (ú3bn) special dividend and a ú1bn share buyback. The dividend will be accompanied by an EPS-smoothing 11-for-12 share consolidation. The shares will go ex-special-dividend on 22 May 2017 with payment due on 2 June 2017. Given the magnitude of the distribution, the share price could suffer once the shares are ex-dividend.
● Otherwise little else has changed: We see National Grid’s refocused portfolio of regulated businesses delivering a c7% CAGR in regulated asset value 2016/17E to 2019/20E. This supports its RPI-linked dividend growth target (which looks achievable), aided by a steady recovery in US returns thanks to ongoing rate filings. National Grid is a net beneficiary of sterling weakness against the dollar (its US profits modestly outweigh its US debt exposure).

11:25 am

11:01 am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:33am

BE11:34am

The FDA has more important things to worry about than price sensitive information, of course, as it's in the business of trying not to kill people.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Still, the information flow around these decisions can seem a wee bit loose sometimes.

PM11:35am

That's interesting

BE11:35am

Let me grab Paul Cuddon of Numis, who's extremely good.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Hikma has received a Complete Response Letter from the FDA in relation to its
abbreviated new drug application for its generic version of GSK's Advair Diskus.
The FDA has categorised the CRL as "Major" and we presume this will incur a
minimum 12-month delay, with a full review of the letter and discussions with
the FDA crucial to resolving the path ahead. Based on the initial assessment no
material issues were raised regarding the substitutability of the proposed device,
which may differentiate Hikma's CRL from Mylan's that were directly related to
Human Factor Studies, as confirmed yesterday. Either way we see potential for
very modest downside (c.1%) to our FY17 forecasts, with our 2,350p valuation
well underpinned by the Injectables, Generics and Branded Divisions. Hikma's Q1
trading update is due next week, which will help refocus attention.

BE11:36am

● A setback, but a potentially a clearer path ahead: Advair is a complex product, with
multiple device, formulation, dosing, useability and manufacturing complexities. There
remains a significant need for lower cost generic options in the class, given the high
patient co-pays and overall costs to the US healthcare system. Hikma was confident
in its application, but has now been given detail of where its application falls short.
Understanding these deficiencies, resolving them and resubmitting is now expected to
extend beyond 2017, with launch now highly unlikely in 2017.

BE11:36am

● Very modest impact on our low-end forecasts: Our forecasts had assumed a delay,
although the Major CRL implies modest downgrades to FY17 (c.1%, $50m in Advair
sales at 10% margins = 1% of Group EBITA). However, with a Q1 trading statement
due on the 19th May we await an update on the generics business as our low-end
forecasts (NSe 118c), may well be resilient while consensus (130c) may need to come
down unless Hikma can significantly improve generic margins without Advair.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

● Bull case scenario now deferred: We had previously articulated a scenario that
foresaw a Major delay for Mylan, and a minor delay for Hikma that could have unlocked
a ú30 per share bull case valuation. On the other hand, our bear case scenario (major
CRL) proposed a 1,983p per share valuation, and with the shares down 8% this
morning, the market is now heavily discounting the core business.

BE11:36am

● Valuation well underpinned: Regardless of Advair, we continue to believe our 2,350p
target is underpinned by the Injectables, Branded and Generics divisions and would
Buy on weakness this morning. Shares trade on 20x FY17 P/E and 11x EV/EBITDA

BE11:37am

Worth emphasising here that it's the bull case that's gone by later approval, rather than the base case.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Mylan stuff had led to investors seeing timely approval as a 50-50 shot.

BE11:37am

You might remember N+1 detailing that argument around Vectura a month or so ago.

Vectura Group PLC (VEC:LSE): Last: 131.80, down 13.1 (-9.04%), High: 138.00, Low: 128.50, Volume: 2.68m
11:37 am
BE11:38am

Speaking of, here's RBC for them.

BE11:38am

Vectura has announced that Hikma, partner on the US VR315 generic Advair program, has received a Major Complete Response Letter (CRL) from the FDA. The companies are now in the process of reviewing the response letter and coordinating further meetings with the FDA but, based on the CLR, Vectura has indicated that, whilst no material issues had been raised concerning the substitutability of the proposed device, the likelihood for approval in 2017 is low. The news is a clear negative for the shares, and we see consensus as c10% too high at the revenue line for 2017 and c25% too high at EBITDA unless R&D spend curbed materially. Whilst the program may still be salvageable, we need further details on the delay to assess properly. Assuming a c12-15-month delay (taking into account the time needed by Vec/Hik to review/address FDA issues), missing we think a launch is unlikely until late 2018/early 2019 at best. As such, we see downside risk to estimates in 2018 and perhaps 2019 as well. The next questions (after likely timings) we believe investors should be asking are on the number of strengths within the ANDA (the delay could work for Vectura to firm up approval across all three strengths, which would be a positive, in our view), where Sandoz is in this process (will this put it ahead of Mylan and Vec/Hik), and finally on the size of the market opportunity for Vectura come 2018/19 given GSK now has a clear run at switching patients to new products.

**** The KPI's form the TV net adds are extremely weak with net adds of only 11k for the quarter (74k Q4 15/16). BT CONTINUES TO DESTROY SHAREHOLDER VALUE BY INVESTING IN +32% COST INFLATION IN AN ENVIRONMENT OF SLOWING CUSTOMER ADDS. All this at a time that fundamentals of the business especially in the public sector and Global services division is worsening, and at a time that to appease the regulator BT needs too increase CAPEX significantly with the resultant pressure on an unsustainable dividend policy (even after today downgrade to dividend forecast a progressive dividend policy is not sustainable, in my view) .

BE11:45am

(@Krapps: it can eke an extra year out of Advair. That's yer reason.)

BE11:45am

** BT'S STRATEGY IS WRONG - POPULAR BELIEF THAT SPORT IS THE MAIN DRAW FOR PAY-TV AND PREMIUM CONTENT IS WRONG - A recent intensive study in UK highlighted that only around 25% of Pay-TV customers chose Sports and football programming as their main reason to subscribe to Pay-TV. Indeed over 60% of the customers were more interested in Entertainment programmes and movies. BT is throwing good money into an abyss with no prospect of real economic return. THE OUTCOME IS INEVITABLE! ANOTHER PROFIT WARNING AND ON TECHNICALS NO SUPPORT UNTIL 22P ONCE WE BREAK 300P. SELL!

11:45 am
PM11:45am

That is contemptuous

BE11:46am

It's a specialist sales note, to be clear. But Saeed's stuff's so good, I'm hoping he doesn't mind us making an exception and quoting it here.

BE11:46am

For something more client friendly, here's Bernstein.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Much has transpired since BT left investors speechless as it reset revenue, EBITDA and FCF expectations for FY16/17 and '17/18. The accounting scandal in Italy precipitated the revision. It also inadvertently thrust the Business and Public Sector segment into the limelight and left us wondering whether BT did indeed 'kitchen sink' the dramatically weaker public sector revenue and EBITDA outlook. Today's Q4 and FY16/17 results and revised FY17/18 guidance including the revised and poorer dividend growth outlook should be evaluated in this context.

BE11:47am

On aggregate, Q4 was not too shabby. Revenues were ahead of consensus by c.1.5%. EBITDA +2.4% vs. expectations. At GBP7,645m, FY EBITDA was a sliver above the c.GBP7.6b range. Consumer growth was just fine albeit modestly slower sequentially. Leading indicators such as broadband net adds were weaker on higher churn stemming from the announced price increase effective April 1st and heightened competition from TalkTalk for a shrinking pool of market gross adds. BT is right to abstain from price competition and focus on balancing future price increases and customer retention. The BPS segment was a positive surprise vs. our numbers and order-book expanded further. This indicates that mobile growth in the SME and LE segment is increasingly offsetting the drag in the public sector. Wholesale & Ventures and Openreach numbers rather nondescript. Global Services was weak and the change in leadership, while expected, long overdue.

PM11:47am

(Dust -- sorry, no update. But i will ask.)

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Disappointing dividend guidance. Company guidance for FY17/18 revenues (flat) and EBITDA (broadly flat after adjusting for pension OPEX and regulation) were broadly what we were expecting. The change in dividend policy to a "progressive dividend in line with EPS" vs. the 10% YoY growth for FY17/18 was not. A confirmation of the 10% dividend growth in concert with the profit warning in January was rather naïve with the benefit of hindsight. Flawless execution will be crucial in order to both deliver some dividend growth and to restore management credibility in the eyes of beleaguered BT investors and the market.

A US private equity group which owns a stake in Airbnb is in talks about buying a shareholding in Vice Media, the millennials-focused news and entertainment group, that would value it at about $5.25bn (£4.1bn)

Sky News has learnt that TPG, which manages investments valued at more than $70bn, has joined a cluster of buyout firms examining a deal to acquire about 10% of Vice for just over $500m (£387m).

The talks have been taking place for several weeks, with other prospective bidders for the minority stake including CVC Capital Partners, according to people close to the situation.
